title: Jormua Ophiolite
text:
The Jormua Ophiolite () is a <a href="ophiolite">remnant</a> of ancient <a href="oceanic%20crust">oceanic</a> <a href="lithosphere">lithosphere</a> near the village of <a href="Jormua">Jormua</a> close to the geographical centre of <a href="Finland">Finland</a>. The rocks of the Jormua Ophiolite formed about 1,950 million years ago in the <a href="Paleoproterozoic">Paleoproteozoic Era</a>. The conditions under which the ocean crust rocks of Jormua formed was likely similar to present-day <a href="Red%20Sea">Red Sea</a>. Thus, a linear sea of this type is thought to have existed between two <a href="continental%20crust">continental</a> landmasses in Finland. At some point this sea closed and the ophiolite was <a href="obduction">obducted</a>.
The Jormua ophiolite is the best preserved one along a larger chain of ophiolites that occur within the Kainuu Schist Belt.
The crustal rocks of the ophiolite include <a href="pillow%20lava">pillow lava</a>, <a href="hyaloclastite">hyaloclastite</a>, <a href="sheeted%20dyke%20complex">sheeted dyke</a>s, <a href="gabbro">gabbro</a>, <a href="plagiogranite">plagiogranite</a> and <a href="ultramafic">ultramafic</a> <a href="cumulate%20rock">cumulate rock</a>. <a href="mantle%20%28geology%29">Mantle</a> rocks exposed in the ophiolite are the <a href="peridotite">peridotite</a> varieties of <a href="lherzolite">lherzolite</a>, <a href="harzburgite">harzburgite</a> and <a href="dunite">dunite</a>.
